[契, 契約, 契約社員] are considered "contract employees" (in Japanese, "契約社員").

Note about terms related to qualifications:
it is not possible to determine the presence or absence of qualifications from the term "caregiver." Even without a caregiving qualification, it is possible to work as a caregiver.

 - Caregivers/Part-Time Employees: For obvious reasons, this title describes exactly what the job entails. There may even be an expectation that you wear formal clothing while providing care, which further emphasizes why part time employees wouldn’t fit well in this role. You may want to mention in your application instructions that candidates must already know how to bathe seniors before getting hired. Another thing to add here would be if the client requires assistance with medication or needs help using the bathroom.
 - Caregivers/Contract Employees: As stated before, it isn’t clear if contract employees require specific licensing to perform these duties. They could easily ask one of their regular employees to fill in temporarily. Contractors usually charge much less than full time employees because of this flexibility. So there’s no reason to assume contractors are required to meet higher standards for customer service and professionalism, unless otherwise specified

A. Caregiver (Correct)
B. Caregiver with Qualification (Wrong - This option refers to someone who has obtained a certain certification or degree in caring for others, but it doesn't necessarily mean they have experience working as a caregiver.)
C. Unqualified Caregiver (Wrong - This option suggests that an individual can be hired as a caregiver regardless of their qualifications, which contradicts the previous statement that it isn't possible to determine the presence or absence of qualifications from the term "caregiver.")
D. Full-Time Employee (Wrong - This option implies that only full-time employees can be caregivers, which is incorrect based on the explanation given earlier about part-time/casual workers being able to work as caregivers.)
E. Part-Time/Casual Worker (Incorrect - This option doesn't make sense based on the other options presented since it implies that a caregiver must hold a specific type of job title, which is contradicted by the earlier explanations about caregivers not needing any particular job title or certification.)

Therefore, the correct answer is A. Caregiver.

data.sampled: Correct answer: D. "ケアスタッフ"(Caregiver) is an appropriate translation for " Hastings Caregiver". However, I would like to provide some context on what "ケアスタッフ" actually means in Japan. In Japan, the term "ケアスタッフ" refers specifically to caregivers who have completed specialized training programs provided by local governments, known as "Long Term Care Insurance Training Programs." These programs typically involve classroom instruction followed by practical experience working with elderly patients in long-term care facilities. Once a caregiver completes this program, they receive certification from the Long Term Care Insurance Agency, which enables them to work in various positions within the industry, including full-time, part-time, and contract jobs such as those listed in your question. Therefore, while "ケアスタッフ" may be translated as "Caregiver," it's important to note that it carries specific meaning within the Japanese language and culture, referring to individuals who have undergone rigorous training and certifications in order to work in this field.
